CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 3 (substantive aspect);Violation of Art. 5-1;Violation of Art. 5-3;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Karel Jungwiert;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . At the material time the applicant held the position of Head of ORG ( начальник PERSON юстиции Сахалинской области ) .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date an external audit commenced in the said ORG and embezzlement of budgetary assets was subsequently established .
CARDINAL . On DATE criminal proceedings were instituted in this connection .
CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME the applicant retained a lawyer .

CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME the applicant was arrested and placed in custody . Being questioned as a suspect in the case , the applicant availed herself of the right to remain silent and applied for release on bail or subject to personal surety .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator in charge refused to release the applicant , stating that , according to LAW , “ a measure of restraint could only be changed in the circumstances when it was no longer needed ” and that “ there were no such circumstances ” in the applicant 's case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant resigned from her position .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator in charge remanded the applicant in custody . The order , which was approved by a deputy prosecutor of LOC , referred to the danger of the applicant 's absconding , the risk of her obstructing the establishment of the truth and influencing the witnesses who had been her subordinates , and to the gravity of the charges against her .
CARDINAL . The applicant 's request to release her subject to the imposition of another measure of restraint was examined and refused by the investigator on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's lawyer appealed to the court against the applicant 's pre - trial detention .

CARDINAL . The application was examined by judge A. of the Yuzhno - Sakhalinsk Town Court ( “ the Town Court ” ) on DATE . At the hearing the applicant and her counsel reiterated their request for the applicant 's release in view of her poor health , the fact that she had family commitments and a good reference from her former place of work . The judge confirmed the lawfulness of the applicant 's remand in custody , having based this decision on “ the evidence in the applicant 's case file , proving that she might abscond or influence the witnesses if released ” .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , the evidence referred to by Judge PERSON was a transcript of an audio tape recording of telephone conversations of another suspect , PERSON During CARDINAL such conversation PERSON stated that “ on DATE PERSON will leave forever ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( “ the Regional Court ” ) upheld the decision of DATE on appeal .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE , formal charges of embezzlement and abuse of power had been brought against the applicant . Since the applicant 's counsel was unable to attend the police station that day , the investigating authorities appointed another lawyer to assist her . However , in the absence of her counsel , the applicant refused to read and sign the decision to charge her .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's lawyer challenged the decision of DATE before the court , claiming that the applicant 's right to defence had been violated . He also requested the court to release the applicant pending trial .

CARDINAL . On DATE judge A. of ORG disallowed the above complaint , having noted that the allegations advanced by the applicant 's representative had already been examined and rejected by the courts during the first judicial review of the applicant 's detention .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG set aside the above decision and discontinued the proceedings in respect of the complaint of DATE . The court noted , inter alia , that the applicant was entitled to appeal against the alleged infringement of her right to defence at the trial stage .
CARDINAL . On DATE the regional prosecutor extended the applicant 's detention until DATE on the ground that she might flee the trial or put pressure on witnesses while at liberty .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged this order before the court , and requested to be released . She maintained , in particular , that she could not hinder the investigation or influence the witnesses , since the audit had terminated on DATE . The applicant also referred to poor conditions of her detention and deterioration of her health .

CARDINAL . On DATE judge A. of ORG dismissed the applicant 's complaint as unfounded , with reference to the gravity of the charges , “ the applicant 's personality ” and “ the evidence in the applicant 's case file , proving that she might abscond or influence the witnesses if released ” . The judge also noted that the investigating authorities had produced a medical report stating that the applicant had no need of medical treatment .

CARDINAL . In her appeal against the decision of CARDINAL DATE the applicant stated , inter alia , that Judge PERSON should have been disqualified from reviewing her detention , as this judge had already considered and rejected her applications for release on CARDINAL previous occasions .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the decision of CARDINAL DATE . With respect to the applicant 's argument concerning Judge PERSON , the court noted that the domestic law entitled a judge to examine a repeated complaint about the lawfulness of detention .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE a deputy prosecutor of LOC refused the applicant 's request for release .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was charged with a number of additional counts relating to embezzlement , abuse of power and forgery .
CARDINAL . On DATE the preliminary investigation was terminated and the applicant and her lawyer began studying the case file .
CARDINAL . On DATE the regional prosecutor ordered the extension of the applicant 's detention until DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the prosecutor 's decision , claiming that she was unable to obstruct the establishment of the truth or influence the witnesses , since the investigation had already terminated . She also referred to her poor state of health .

CARDINAL . On DATE judge B. of ORG dismissed the applicant 's complaint , holding that her detention was “ in accordance with law ” and necessary in view of the seriousness of the charges and the applicant 's personality . The judge also took note of medical certificates produced by the applicant 's lawyer as well as the aforementioned medical report adduced by the investigating body , and found the applicant 's allegations that she was in poor health unsubstantiated .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the above decision on appeal . The court noted that the applicant was charged with a serious criminal offence and its severity alone could , according to LAW , permit her continued detention .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's counsel lodged a complaint against the investigator in charge , requesting the court to order the applicant 's inpatient examination by an independent medical authority .

CARDINAL . On DATE Judge PERSON of ORG declined jurisdiction to examine the complaint , stating that it fell within the competence of the prosecutor . This decision was upheld on appeal by ORG on DATE .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , the regional prosecutor extended the period of the applicant 's remand in custody until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed to the court against the prosecutor 's order . Her complaint was assigned to Judge PERSON of ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant sought the withdrawal of the judge . On DATE dismissed the challenge .

CARDINAL . At the hearing on DATE the applicant and her defence counsel claimed that the preliminary investigation had been completed , that the applicant had finished studying her case file , and that therefore the investigating authorities had no reasons to believe that the applicant might flee or obstruct the establishment of the truth if at large . Moreover , the applicant posed no danger to the public and suffered from various health problems , which required proper medical treatment .

CARDINAL . Having heard the parties , Judge PERSON found that the applicant should remain in custody , on account of the gravity of the charges and the risk of her absconding . The judge further rejected the applicant 's complaints about her health as groundless . This decision was upheld on appeal by ORG on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator refused to release the applicant , making a general reference to the absence of any circumstances proving that her detention was no longer needed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's case was forwarded to ORG for examination .
CARDINAL . On DATE Judge PERSON of ORG remitted the case for a further investigation and stated that the applicant should remain in custody in view of the seriousness of the charges .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the above decision in so far as it concerned her detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal .
CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on CARDINAL DATE the deputy ORG had authorised the applicant 's detention until DATE . This order was served on the applicant on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged the extension of her custody period before ORG , complaining , in particular , that she had not been notified of the order of CARDINAL DATE in time .

DATE . At the hearing on DATE the applicant also referred to the poor state of her health and the absence of any risk that she might abscond or hinder the investigation , which was at an end . Her arguments were examined and rejected as unfounded . Having acknowledged the fact that the order of CARDINAL DATE had not been served on the applicant in due time , the court held that this fact did not affect the legal force of the extension order or the lawfulness of the applicant 's detention . It therefore ordered the applicant 's continued detention , with reference to the gravity of the charges against her . On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested the investigator to release her .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator informed the applicant that there were no reasons to release her .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was again transferred to ORG for examination on the merits .

CARDINAL . On DATE Judge PERSON of ORG scheduled a hearing in the applicant 's case and held that “ in view of the gravity of the charges [ against the applicant ] the measure of restraint applied to her should remain unchanged ” . The decision did not specify the time - limit for the applicant 's detention , nor did it refer to any other matters regarding the lawfulness of her detention .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against the above decision in so far as it related to her detention . She claimed that DATE , when the period of her remand in custody had expired , and DATE her detention had had no basis in domestic law . She further complained that the court had ignored her submissions about the state of her health .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's appeal , finding that her detention was lawful . The court stated that the applicant had been charged with serious crimes , and could be detained on the sole ground of the dangerousness of those offences . With regard to the applicant 's argument concerning her detention DATE and DATE , the court noted that the applicant 's case file , including the indictment , had been transmitted to court on DATE , before the period of her remand in custody had expired . Accordingly , in the court 's opinion , the statutory provisions governing the time - limit for detention during the preliminary investigation had been complied with in respect of the applicant . The court further stated that , upon referral of the case to court , the first instance had taken its decision in due time , as prescribed by LAW .

CARDINAL . The applicant 's further requests for release were rejected by ORG on DATE and DATE with a reference to the absence of any “ new grounds for altering [ the applicant 's ] measure of restraint ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Yuzhno - Sakhalinsk Town Court , composed of Judge PERSON and CARDINAL lay assessors , convicted the applicant , along with another co - accused , of embezzlement , forgery and abuse of power , and sentenced DATE and DATE imprisonment and confiscation of her property .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the sentence , having lifted the charges against the applicant on CARDINAL counts with reference to a limitation period .
CARDINAL . Thereafter the applicant applied unsuccessfully for a supervisory review .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was released on parole .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , from DATE until DATE she was kept in the temporary holding facility of ORG of the ORG ( изолятор временного содержания управления внутренних дел г. Южно-Сахалинска , “ the ORG ” ) . In support of that submission , the applicant enclosed the authorities ' letters dated CARDINAL and DATE respectively sent to her at the address of the ORG .

CARDINAL . The ORG was situated in the basement of the LOC of ORG . Following her arrest the applicant was placed in a cell measuring CARDINAL x QUANTITY which was QUANTITY high . There were no windows in the cell , with the result that there was no natural light , nor any fresh air . There was no toilet bowl or any other installation in the cell , and the applicant had to use the sink for her needs . The cell was overrun with mice , rats , lice , cockroaches and fungus .

CARDINAL . The applicant was not allowed to take any toiletries or a change of clothes with her . She was not provided with any bedding and had to sleep on a plain wooden plank bed . During DATE of her detention the applicant was not given any food or drinking water .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in the evening , the applicant was transferred to another cell which accommodated CARDINAL other inmates . The conditions in that cell were similar to those described above . They stretched a piece of cloth over the top to try to reduce the smell . TIME the cellmates took the tank out of the cell to the common toilet and washed it in turn using a hose with cold water . The detainees were taken to shower no more than once a week ; they were not given soap or any other toiletries or a change of clean underwear . DATE . The applicant was allowed to receive food from her relatives , but , in her submission , she was hardly able to eat given that she had gastrointestinal problems and because of the poor sanitary conditions in the cell . The applicant , who suffered from heart , gastrointestinal and gynaecological conditions , was prohibited from receiving any medicines which she had been taking prior to her detention from her family with the result that her state of health deteriorated . She insisted on an independent gynaecological examination as well as examinations by a dermatologist and an ophthalmologist .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a duty paramedic in connection with the inflammation of her face . She was diagnosed with allergic dermatitis and prescribed antihistamine pills and ointment .
CARDINAL . DATE the applicant was examined by a psychiatrist in connection with her complaints of insomnia and itching and eruptions on her face . The doctor concluded that she was “ almost fit ” .

CARDINAL . NORP On CARDINAL DATE the applicant was examined by a duty paramedic in connection with her complaints of nausea , weakness and shooting pains in the heart area . She was diagnosed with presumed cardio neurosis and prescribed relevant treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the applicant 's complaint to the effect that she was unable to take part in a court hearing scheduled for DATE because of her poor physical condition , she was examined by a general practitioner who concluded that she was fit .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant was examined by a dermatologist in connection with her complaint of eruptions on her face . She was diagnosed with allergic dermatitis and prescribed antihistamines , vitamins and ointments .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a general practitioner who diagnosed her with presumed osteochondrosis and premenopausal syndrome and prescribed relevant treatment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by the head of the IZCARDINAL/CARDINAL medical office , who concluded that her dermatological condition was satisfactory .
CARDINAL . DATE the applicant was examined by a dermatologist who also confirmed that she was fit .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant had a conversation with the head of the IZ-CARDINAL/CARDINAL medical office as regards the administration of medicines for treatment of heart disease received from the applicant 's family members . The applicant was invited to undergo an electrocardiographic monitoring necessary prior to the administration of that medicine , but she refused the monitoring , stating that the device was outdated .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was attended and examined by the head of the Tselitel medical centre , who concluded that the applicant was suffering from premenopausal syndrome and suggested that she undergo treatment with hormonal medicines .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a general practitioner , who diagnosed her with influenza and administered relevant treatment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a general practitioner , who found that she had post - cholecystectomy syndrome . She was prescribed relevant treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a duty paramedic as she stated that she had been on hunger strike since DATE . The paramedic weighed the applicant and took her blood pressure . Her physical condition was found to be satisfactory .

CARDINAL . On DATE a general practitioner examined the applicant , took her blood pressure and , at the applicant 's request , prescribed her the medicines which had been delivered by her family members .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a general practitioner and diagnosed with influenza . Relevant treatment was prescribed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a duty paramedic in connection with her complaint of headaches and weakness . The paramedic found that she had vegetative - vascular dystonia and recommended relevant treatment .
CARDINAL . On DATE a general practitioner diagnosed the applicant with acute laryngotracheitis and prescribed relevant treatment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was attended and treated by a general practitioner in connection with pharyngitis and vegetative - vascular dystonia .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a general practitioner , diagnosed with acute tracheobronchitis and prescribed relevant treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was attended and treated by a general practitioner in connection with protracted tracheitis . On DATE the general practitioner again examined the applicant and recommended that the treatment be continued .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a general practitioner and diagnosed with follicular tonsillitis . Relevant treatment was prescribed . On DATE she was attended by a duty paramedic who recommended that she continue with the treatment .

CARDINAL . During the period of her detention in remand centre IZ-CARDINAL/CARDINAL the applicant underwent fluorography examinations on CARDINAL occasions ; the examination disclosed no pathologies .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator in charge ordered the seizure of the applicant 's flat pending trial .
CARDINAL . On DATE a deputy regional prosecutor rejected the applicant 's complaint against the investigator 's order .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to a court , stating that the flat in question was the only housing for her family and therefore was immune from seizure .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Yuzhno - Sakhalinsk Town Court found in the applicant 's favour and lifted the seizure .
CARDINAL . On DATE , on an appeal by the regional prosecutor , ORG quashed the above judgment and remitted the case to the first - instance court .

CARDINAL . It appears that , following the applicant 's conviction , on DATE , ORG lifted the seizure of the applicant 's flat in a separate set of proceedings . The court noted that this apartment was the permanent place of residence for the applicant 's family and was not subject to confiscation .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG discontinued the proceedings on the applicant 's action of DATE , since she had waived her claims .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ( Taking into custody ) provides that taking into custody as a measure of restraint may be imposed in cases concerning criminal offences punishable by law with DATE imprisonment . The LAW also refers to a number of serious criminal offences , including embezzlement , and provides that in respect of persons charged with those offences , taking into custody as a preventive measure may be applied on the sole ground of the danger presented by the criminal offence committed .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ( Periods of detention ) provides that the duration of detention during the investigation of criminal cases may not exceed DATE . This period may be extended by a relevant prosecutor to DATE , and further detention can be authorised by a regional prosecutor ( or a prosecutor of equal rank ) to up to a maximum of DATE . Extension of detention beyond DATE is allowed in exceptional cases only with regard to persons charged with serious criminal offences , and can be authorised by a deputy Prosecutor General for a period of DATE , and by ORG for a period of up to one and a half years . Further extension of detention is not allowed : the person must be released immediately .
